facts.text: Shrine and tomb known as Darga Hazarat Syed Salar Mahsood Ghazi situated in village of Singha Parasi.

anchor.surface_text: The suit from which this appeal arises relates to a shrine and tomb known as Darga Hazarat Syed Salar Mahsood Ghazi situated in the village of Singha Parasi and properties appurtenant to it.

facts.text: Plaintiffs are members of the Waqf Committee, Darga Sharif, Bharaich.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs who have preferred this appeal are members of the Waqf Committee, Darga Sharif, Bharaich, and, in their suit,

facts.text: Claim declaration that properties not covered by United Provinces Muslims Waqfs Act, U.P. XIII of 1936.

anchor.surface_text: they have claimed a declaration that the properties in suit were number companyered by the provisions of the United Provinces Muslims Waqfs Act  U. P. XIII of 1936   hereinafter described as the Act .

facts.text: Respondent 1 is Sunni Central Board of Waqf, United Provinces of Agra and Oudh.

anchor.surface_text: The declaration, the companysequential injunction and the two other subsidiary reliefs are claimed primarily against respondent 1, the Sunni Central Board of Waqf, United Provinces of Agra and Oudh.

facts.text: Respondent 1 issued notification on February 26, 1944, declaring properties waqf under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the provisions of the Act, respondent I was companystituted and, under s. 5 1 , it issued the numberification on February 26, 1944, declaring the properties in suit to be a Sunni Waqf under the Act.

facts.text: Trial court held properties not waqf as defined by the Act on April 15, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial judge held that the properties in suit cannot be held to be waqf as defined by the Act. In his opinion it was number the village Singha Parasi but its profits free from land revenue that had been granted in trust for the shrine and its khadims

facts.text: High Court reversed trial court, held properties constitute waqf under Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has reversed the finding of the trial companyrt on the question as to the character of the properties in suit. According to the High Court the said properties companystituted waqf as defined by the Act.

facts.text: High Court held suit barred by limitation under s.52 of Act and no notice under s.53.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has also held that the suit filed by the appellants was barred by limitation and was also in- companypetent in view of the fact that the statutory numberice required by s. 53 of the Act had number been given by the appellants prior to its institution.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on September 16, 1958 by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. September 16. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by 1289 GAJENDRAGADKAR J.-The suit from which this appeal arises relates to a shrine and tomb

facts.text: Syed Salar Mahsood Ghazi buried in village Singha Parasi.

anchor.surface_text: It is believed that Syed Salar Mahsood Ghazi was a nephew of Muhammad Ghazni and he met his death at the hands of a local chieftain when he paid a visit to Bahraich. On his death his remains were buried in village Singha Parasi by his followers

facts.text: Oudh annexed in 1856, properties confiscated then revived.

anchor.surface_text: Whilst the management of the Darga was being thus carried on, Oudh came to be annexed in 1856 and the proclamation issued by Lord Canning companyfiscated all private properties and inams in the said State.

facts.text: Sanad granted to Fakirulla in 1859 or 1860 for rent-free tenure of village Singha Parasi.

anchor.surface_text: It would appear that in 1859 or 1860 a Sanad had been granted to Fakirulla who was the head of the khadims in respect of rent-free tenure of the village Singha Parasi.

facts.text: Suit No. 1 of 1865 by Inayatulla dismissed on November 11, 1870.

anchor.surface_text: The grantees son Inayatulla was apparently number satisfied with the limited rights granted under the Sanad and so he brought an action, Suit No. 1 of 1865, claiming proprietary rights in the said properties. Inayatullas suit was substantially dismissed on November 11, 1870,

facts.text: Government took possession under Pensions Act XXIII of 1873 after 1878 report.

anchor.surface_text: In the interest of the Darga, Government then decided to take possession of the properties under the provisions of Pensions Act,  XXIII of 1873.  This decision was reached after the Government had companysidered the report made by the Deputy Commissioner on August 31, 1878.

facts.text: Suit by Inayatulla in 1892 dismissed on appeal July 20, 1897.

anchor.surface_text: During this period Inayatulla attempted to assert his rights once more by instituting a suit in the civil companyrt in 1892. ... on appeal the said decree was set aside on July 20, 1897.

facts.text: Suit No. 9 of 1902 under s.539 CPC decreed December 3, 1902, vesting properties in trustees and scheme framed.

anchor.surface_text: the Legal Remembrancer to the Government of the United Provinces of Agra and Oudh filed a suit, No. 9 of 1902, under s. 539  present s. 92  of the Code of Civil Procedure. This suit ended in a decree on December 3, 1902.

facts.text: Suit No. 1 of 1934, District Judge order on May 7, 1934 restricting spending of Darga funds on litigation.

anchor.surface_text: In 1934 Ashraf Ali and others clamed  Suit No. 1 of 1934  ... On May 7, 1934, the learned District Judge ... issued an order directing the defendant companymittee that numbermoney out of the Darga funds should be spent

facts.text: Suit No. 1 of 1940 decreed October 16, 1941, appeal succeeded March 7, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: This peace was, however, again disturbed in 1940 when a suit was filed  No. 1 of 1940  ... On October 16, 1941, the suit was decreed. ... on March 7, 1946, the decree under appeal was set aside

holdings.text: The suit falls within the mischief of Section 5(2) of the Act because 'any person interested in a waqf' includes persons interested in a transaction held to be a waqf, even those denying waqf status, and is thus barred by the one-year limitation unless saved by Section 15 of the Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is well-settled that in construing the provisions of a statute courts should be slow to adopt a construction which tends to make any part of the statute meaningless or ineffective an attempt must always be made so to reconcile the relevant provisions

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction to avoid rendering part of statute meaningless; scheme of s.5(2) contemplates challenges to waqf determinations; analogy to s.33 Arbitration Act.

holdings.text: The suit is not saved by Section 15 of the Limitation Act as there was no injunction or order expressly or impliedly staying institution of the suit; prior order in 1940 suit restricting management interference does not qualify.

anchor.surface_text: s. 15 of the Limitation Act. That is the only provision on which reliance was placed before us by Mr. Dar on behalf of the appellants. Section 15. provides for the exclusion of time during which proceedings are suspended

holdings.reasoning_summary: Strict grammatical construction required for limitation provisions; equitable considerations irrelevant; precedents from Privy Council (Narayan Jivangouda, Beti Maharani) require express/implied stay of suit institution specifically.

holdings.text: The suit is barred by limitation under Section 5(2) of the Act as filed beyond one year from notification without exclusion under s.15.

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly hold that the High Court was right in taking the view that s. 15 did not apply to the present suit and that it was therefore filed beyond the period of one year prescribed by s. 5 2 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.5(2) applies per liberal construction; no s.15 exclusion; upholds High Court.

holdings.text: No suit maintainable under Section 53 without two months' prior notice to Central Board; notification under s.5(1) covers Darga/tomb and accretions like offerings; no notice given.

anchor.surface_text: That takes us to the consideration of the next preliminary objection against the competence of the suit under s. 53 of the Act. Section 53 provides that no suit shall be instituted against a Central Board in respect of any act purporting to be done by such Central Board under colour of this Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification explicitly includes tomb; offerings are income/accretions not needing separate listing; s.53 mandatory like s.80 CPC; suit seeks relief re waqf acts.

holdings.text: Question whether properties constitute waqf under the Act not decided.

anchor.surface_text: Since we have reached the conclusion that the High Court was right in holding that the suit was barred under s. 5 2  and was also incompetent under s. 53 of the Act, we do not propose to decide the question as to whether the properties in dispute are waqf within the meaning of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary as suit dismissed on preliminary objections of limitation and notice.

precedents.citation: Chaturbhuj Mohanlal v. Bhicam Chand Chororia Sons

anchor.surface_text: This liberal construction has been put upon the clause in several judicial decisions Chaturbhuj Mohanlal v. Bhicam Chand Chororia Sons Mathu Kutty v. Varoe Kutty  2  Lal Chand Messrs. Basanta Mal

precedents.case_name: Chaturbhuj Mohanlal v. Bhicam Chand Chororia & Sons
precedents.cited_proposition: liberal construction of 'any party to an arbitration agreement' in s.33 of Arbitration Act despite disputing existence

anchor.surface_text: Sons Mathu Kutty v. Varoe Kutty  2  Lal Chand Messrs. Basanta Mal Devi Dayal Ors.  3 . We may also point out incidentally that in dealing with an application made under s. 34 of the Arbitration Act, it is incumbent upon the court to decide first of all whether there is a binding agreement for arbitration between the parties in other words, the allegation by one party against another that there is a valid agreement of reference between them does not preclude the latter party from disputing the existence of the said agreement in proceedings taken under s. 34.

precedents.cited_proposition: liberal construction of statutory clause alleging party status in arbitration despite denial

precedents.citation: Lal Chand Messrs. Basanta Mal Devi Dayal Ors.

anchor.surface_text: Kutty  2  Lal Chand Messrs. Basanta Mal Devi Dayal Ors.  3 . We may also point out incidentally that in dealing with an application made under s. 34 of the Arbitration Act, it is incumbent upon the court to decide first of all whether there is a binding agreement for arbitration between the parties in other words, the allegation by one party against another that there is a valid agreement of reference between them does not preclude the latter party from disputing the existence of the said agreement in proceedings taken under s. 34. These decisions illustrate the principle that where the literal meaning of the words use in a statutory provision would manifestly defeat its object by making a part of it meaningless and ineffective, it is legitimate and even necessary to adopt the rule of liberal construction so as to give meaning to all parts of the provision and to make the whole of it effective and operative.

precedents.case_name: Lal Chand v. Basanta Mal Devi Dayal & Ors.
precedents.cited_proposition: liberal construction of statutory language to avoid ineffectiveness

precedents.citation: Nagendra Nath Dey v. Suresh Chandra Dey

anchor.surface_text: but there can be no doubt that, in construing provisions of limitation, equitable considerations are immaterial and irrelevant and in applying them effect must be given to the strict grammatical meaning of the words used by them Nagendra Nath Dey v. Suresh Chandra Dey  1 . In considering the effect of the provisions contained in s. 15, it would be useful to refer to the decision of the Privy Council in Narayan Jivangouda v. Puttabai  2 .

precedents.case_name: Nagendra Nath Dey v. Suresh Chandra Dey
precedents.cited_proposition: in construing limitation provisions, equitable considerations immaterial; strict grammatical meaning

anchor.surface_text: the decision of the Privy Council in Narayan Jivangouda v. Puttabai  2 . This case was an offshoot of the well-known case of Bhimabai v. Gurunathgouda  3 . It is apparent that the dispute between Narayan and Gurunathgouda ran through a long and protracted course and it reached the Privy Council twice.

precedents.cited_proposition: strict construction of s.15 Limitation Act; injunction must expressly stay institution of suit

anchor.surface_text: offshoot of the well-known case of Bhimabai v. Gurunathgouda  3 . It is apparent that the dispute between Narayan and Gurunathgouda ran through a long and protracted course and it reached the Privy Council twice. The decision of the, Privy Council in Bhimabais case  1  upholding the validity of Narayans adoption no doubt led to a radical change in the accepted and current view about the Hindu widows power to adopt in the State of Bombay, but this decision was of poor consolation to Narayan because the judgment of the Privy Council in Narayan, Jivangoudas case  2  shows that Narayans subsequent suit to recover possession of the properties in his adoptive family was dismissed as barred by time.

precedents.cited_proposition: validity of adoption leading to change in law on Hindu widow's power

anchor.surface_text: Bhimabai and Narayan appealed to the Bombay High Court, but their appeal failed and was dismissed Bhimabai v. Gurunathgouda  3 . There was a further appeal by the said parties to the Privy Council. The Privy Council held that the adoption of Narayan was valid and so the appeal was allowed and Gurunathgoudas suit was dismissed with costs throughout.

precedents.cited_proposition: dismissal of appeal on adoption validity at High Court level
injunction in prior suit does not attract s.15 to subsequent suit
no extension of s.15 on equitable grounds; institution not futile to stop limitation
precedents.cited_holding: institution of a suit can never be said to be futile if it would thereby prevent the running of limitation

precedents.citation: Beti Maharani v. The Collector of Etawah
precedents.case_name: Beti Maharani v. Collector of Etawah
precedents.cited_proposition: attachment before judgment does not stay institution of suit under s.15 Limitation Act
precedents.cited_holding: no violation until creditor receives debt; suit proper to avoid time bar

precedents.cited_proposition: no equitable grounds added to suspend cause of action under Limitation Act s.15

precedents.citation: Musammat Basso Kaur v. Lala Dhua Singh
precedents.case_name: Musammat Basso Kaur v. Lala Dhua Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: observation on avoiding vain litigation to prevent limitation bar (treated as obiter)
